Recipe.Description: I first had this in San Juan, Puerto Rico. In the course of running around we decided we were hungry and told our taxi driver (an older gent named Larry) so. He started to tell us about the best restaurants in town, but we insisted on him talking us to where he'd go for lunch. We ended up in this hole in the wall place with cold Red Stripe beer and a menu written in charcoal on the wall, in Spanish of course. Larry translated for us when I couldn't figure out what turned out to be fried plantains (a kind of banana). I thought sopa frijoles negro meant black bean soup and Larry said 'si'. He explained how it was Cuban in origin and that there was none better to be found in all of Puerto Rico and he thought he'd have some. We had some kind of excellent barbecued shredded pork and fried plantains. I also had the black bean soup, and have been hooked on it ever since.

Prerequisites.Prerequisite: Rinse beans, pick out rocks, bugs, etc. Cover with water and allow to soak over night.

Ingredient.Name: Pork
Ingredient.Notes: Either pork shoulder (butt), neck bones, shank (ham)

Ingredient.Name: Cayenne or de Arbol pepper, dried

Method.Step: In a large stock pot heat bacon grease until it starts to smoke, Add pork and brown thoroughly, stirring as needed for even browning.
Lower heat to medium, add onion and bell pepper and cook until softened and slightly browned.
Add the chicken stock to the pot, bring to a boil.
Add the beans, garlic, cumin, thyme, bay leaves, black and red pepper, cumin and salt.
Once it returns to a boil, cover pot with a lid and reduce to a simmer for 2-4 hours, until beans are tender and meat is falling apart.
Serve with a mound of white rice, a dollop of sour cream, a drizzle of olive oil and garnish with green onion and avocado slices.
